What is computer forensics?

Computer forensics is the application of investigation and analysis techniques to gather and preserve evidence from a particular computing device in a way that is suitable for presentation in a court of law. The goal of computer forensics is to perform a structured investigation and maintain a documented chain of evidence to find out exactly what happened on a computing device and who was responsible for it. Computer forensics -- which is sometimes referred to as computer forensic science essentially is data recovery with legal compliance guidelines to make the information admissible in legal proceedings. The terms digital forensics and cyber forensics are often used as synonyms for computer forensics. Digital forensics starts with the collection of information in a way that maintains its integrity. Investigators then analyze the data or system to determine if it was changed, how it was changed and who made the changes. The use of computer forensics isn't always tied to a crime. The forensic process is also used as part of data recovery processes to gather data from a crashed server, failed drive, reformatted operating system (OS) or other situation where a system has unexpectedly stopped working.

Why is computer forensics important?

In the civil and criminal justice system, computer forensics helps ensure the integrity of digital evidence presented in court cases. As computers and other data-collecting devices are used more frequently in every aspect of life, digital evidence and the forensic process used to collect, preserve and investigate it -- has become more important in solving crimes and other legal issues.

Crime, like so many things in our social world, has a certain taken-for-granted or common-sense nature. When we use the term, we assume the category is meaningful; that is, we assume that those to whom we are talking will understand what we’re

talking about and will tend to use the term in the same way as we do. This, of course, is the basis upon which the social world operates on assumptions about the taken-for-granted meaningfulness of the vocabulary we use and the behaviours we enact. The word crime is used regularly in everyday conversation. That it is used in this manner implies that there is a sufficient level of common understanding for it to be meaningful. On one level, this is undoubtedly the case.

courseDetails.title: PRINCE2 Foundation | 6 Simulation Exams - Update 2023
courseDetails.shortDescription: Everything you need to pass the PRINCE2 | PRINCE 2 Foundation Exam
courseDetails.longDescription:
The PRINCE2 | PRINCE 2 Foundation certification is an entry-level certification that provides the theoretical knowledge of the PRINCE2 project management method. It covers the seven principles, seven themes, and seven processes of PRINCE2.

The PRINCE2 method is a structured and flexible approach to project management that can be used in a variety of industries and project types. It is based on the following seven principles:

  • Business Case: The project must have a clear business case that justifies its existence.

  • Benefits: The project must deliver benefits to the organization.

  • Tailoring: The PRINCE2 method should be tailored to the specific needs of the project.

  • Defined Roles and Responsibilities: Everyone involved in the project must know their roles and responsibilities.

  • Management by Exception: Only significant deviations from the plan should be reported.

  • Plans: Plans should be produced at all levels of the project and should be updated regularly.

  • Configuration Management: All project products must be managed and controlled.

  • Communication: Effective communication is essential for the success of any project.

The PRINCE2 Foundation exam is a multiple-choice exam that tests your knowledge of the PRINCE2 method. The exam is 60 minutes long and consists of 60 questions. The pass mark is 55%, so you need to answer at least 33 questions correctly to pass.

The questions are based on the seven principles, seven themes, and seven processes of PRINCE2. They may ask you to define a principle, explain a theme, or describe a process. They may also ask you to apply a principle, theme, or process to a specific scenario.

WHY CHOOSE US?

  • 06 SETS OF PRACTICE EXAMS: Immerse yourself in unique and up-to-date questions meticulously tailored to align with the certification exam format.

  • SIMULATE THE ACTUAL CERTIFICATION EXAM: Emulate the actual exam environment through timed and scored tests, bolstering your confidence and poise.
